Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) that satisfies the differential equation \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Pz + Qi \\), where P and Q are constants. We analyze the behavior under a Fourier transform given by \\( F(z)(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty z(t)e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\).

If at a particular time \\( t_1 \\), an intervention by applying another transformation \\( G(z) = z^2 \\) is made, will the resulting spectrum \\( F(z)(\\omega) \\) at any time T > t_1 depend solely on the differential equation without any effect from the initial Fourier transformation?
Explanation: The intervention of \\( G(z) = z^2 \\) significantly modifies the function, adding non-linear alterations to its evolution. As such, even if the function continues to evolve under the same differential equation post-intervention, the spectrum \\( F(z)(\\omega) \\) will reflect the compounded effects of the original Fourier transform, the differential equation, and the non-linear intervention.
